p: Although Bufo bufo is expected to bring forward its breeding activity after mild winters ( Reading, 1998, 2003; Tryjanowski, Rybacki & Sparks, 2003), at least three lines of support may help explaining this apparently counter-intuitive pattern. In years, when the breeding season begins earlier (after a mild winter), breeding has been observed to last longer ( Gittins, Parker & Slater, 1980). Furthermore, a second and lower peak of breeding activity has been often observed later in the season ( Pages, 1984; Reading, 1998), especially after mild winters ( Reading, 1998). Finally, extensive ecophysiological investigations on bufonid toads, including Bufo bufo, indicate that increased temperatures during hibernation lead to significant alterations of several processes affecting the breeding activity, including body size condition, annual ovarian cycle, and seasonal synchronisation of breeding ( JÃ¸rgensen, 1992).
